review.title: PSMACA: An Automated Protein Structure Prediction Using MACA (Multiple Attractor Cellular Automata)
review.abstract: Protein Structure Predication from sequences of amino acid has gained a remarkable attention in recent years. Even though there are some prediction techniques addressing this problem, the approximate accuracy in predicting the protein structure is closely 75%. An automated procedure was evolved with MACA (Multiple Attractor Cellular Automata) for predicting the structure of the protein. Most of the existing approaches are sequential which will classify the input into four major classes and these are designed for similar sequences. PSMACA is designed to identify ten classes from the sequences that share twilight zone similarity and identity with the training sequences. This method also predicts three states (helix, strand, and coil) for the structure. Our comprehensive design considers 10 feature selection methods and 4 classifiers to develop MACA (Multiple Attractor Cellular Automata) based classifiers that are build for each of the ten classes. We have tested the proposed classifier with twilight-zone and 1-high-similarity benchmark datasets with over three dozens of modern competing predictors shows that PSMACA provides the best overall accuracy that ranges between 77% and 88.7% depending on the dataset.

Kiran Sree1, Inampudi Ramesh Babu2, and N. Usha Devi3, India 3Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad 500085, India2Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Acharya Nagarjuna University, Guntur 522510, India 3Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Kakinada 533003, IndiaProtein Structure Predication from Sequetcies of Prediction of Aminoacid has received a remarkable attention in recent years, although there are some problems associated with classification of three classes.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: They are macrostructured molecules responsible for a wide range of vital biochemical functions that function as oxygen, cell signalling, antibody production, nutrient transport and muscle fiber buildup. Specifically, the proteins are chains of amino acids, of which there are 20 different types, coupled to peptide bonds.2 The three-tiered structural hierarchy possessed by proteins is typically referred to as primary and tertiary structure.The protein structure prediction of amino acids lends enormous value to the biological community because the higher levels and secondary levels determine the function of proteins and hence insight into their function can be derived from it. Genome sequence sequence structure projects are increasing enormously. SWISS-PORT databases3 of primary protein structures are expanding enormously.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORKS IN STRUCTURE PREDICTION
sections.text: The aim of structural prediction is to determine whether the amino acid residue of the protein is present in a helix, strand or other form. In 1960, as an initiative step of structural prediction, the probability of the respective structural element for each amino acid is calculated by considering the properties of individual amino acids. 3 6 This method of structural prediction is considered a first generation technique. Later, this work was expanded by taking into account the local environment of the amino acid, which is considered a second generation technique. In the case of certain amino acid structural predictions, which are also needed, it takes into account the local environment of the amino acid, which it provides 65% structural information. Thus, this expansion work gives 60% accuracy. The third generation of the technique involves machine learning, knowledge of proteins, set of algorithms that give 70% accuracy. Neural networks 10 11 are also useful in implementing structural prediction programs such as PHD, SAM-99 to adapt the basic algorithm of the CA to be used by the evolutionary algorithm of the CA to determine the structure of the CA.

sections.heading: 3. CELLULAR AUTOMATA
sections.text: Cellular Automata (CA) is a simple model of a spatially expanded decentralized system composed of a number of individual components (cells); communication between constituent cells is limited to local interaction; each cell is in a specific state that changes over time according to the states of its neighbors; from the days of Neumann, who first proposed the Cellular Automata (CA) model, to 24 25, to Wolfram's recent book, "A New Kind of Science," CA's simple and local neighborhood structure has attracted researchers from various disciplines; it has undergone rigorous mathematical and physical analysis over the past fifty years, and its application has been proposed in various branches of science - both social and physical.

sections.heading: 4. DESIGN OF MACA BASED PATTERN CLASSIFIER
sections.text: An n-bit MACA with k-attractor basins can be considered a natural classifier. It classifies a given set of patterns into k-number of different classes, with each class containing the set of states in the attractor basin. To increase the classification accuracy of the machine, most works use MACA as shown in Figure 2 to classify patterns into two classes (say I and II). The following example shows 212 J. Bioinf. Intell. Control 2, 211-215, 2013R E S E A R C H A R T IC L example illustrates a MACA25 26 based two-class pattern classifier.

sections.heading: 4.1. PSMACA Tree Building
sections.text: Input: Training set S = S1 S2 SK Output: PSMACA Tree.Partition (S, K) Step 1: Generate a PSMACA with k number of attractor pools. Step 2: Distribute S into k attractor pools (nodes). Step 3: Evaluate the distribution of examples in each attractor pool. Step 4: If all examples (S ′) of an attractor pool (node) belong to only one class, then label the attractor pool (leaf node) for that class. Step 5: Belong examples (S ′) of an attractor pool to K ′ number of classes, then partition (S ′, K ′). Step 6: Stop.

sections.heading: 4.2. Random Generation of Initial Population
sections.text: To form the initial population, it must be ensured that each randomly generated solution is a combination of an n-bit DS with 2 m number of attractor pools (classifier # 1) and an m-bit DV (classifier # 2). Chromosomes are randomly synthesized according to the following steps: 1. Random division n into m number of integers so that n1 + n2 + · · · + nm = n. 2. For each ni randomly generate a valid dependence vector (DV) 3. Synthesize a chromosome by concatenating m number of DVs for classifier # 1. 4. Random synthesis of an m-bit dependence vector (DV) for classifier # 2. 5. Synthesize a chromosome by concatenating classifier # 1 and classifier # 2.

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
sections.text: • Select the target CA protein (amino acid sequence) T, whose structure is to be predicted. • Perform a PSMACA search using the primary amino acid sequence Tp of the target CA protein T. The goal is to find a set of CA proteins with a similar sequence. • Select from S the primary structure Bp of a base CA protein with significant agreement with the target CA protein. • A PSMACA, 16 18 search generates a measure of the similarity between each CA protein in S and the target CA protein T. Therefore, Bp can be selected as the CA protein with the highest such value. • Get the structure of the base CA protein, Bs, from the PDB. • Create an input sequence Ib (which corresponds to the base CA protein) by predicting each amino acid 200 in the 600 primary protein sequence, Bs, from the PDB. • Create an output sequence Ib (which corresponds to the base CA protein) by replacing each amino acid 200 in the 600 primary protein sequence with the helium 600 strand structure of the hypothetical element.

sections.heading: 6. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: In the experiments carried out, the values 200,600,800 for Helix C, strand and coil are assigned to the base proteins. We have found a structure numbering scheme based on Boolean characters of CA, which separately predicts the coils, states and spirals. sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Existing structure prediction methods can predict the structure with 75% accuracy. Our preliminary results suggest that such a level of accuracy is achievable and potentially can be surpassed with our method. PSMACA provides the best general accuracy, ranging from 77% to 88.7% depending on the dataset.214 J. Bioinf. Intell. Control 2, 211-215, 2013R E E A R H R T IC L EReferences and Notes1.
